author: By     Claudia Assis
title: Truck of the future weds hybrid and solar technologies
text:
The semi-truck of the future is here, and it’s a hybrid-electric tractor towing a refer trailer cooled by the sun.
Daimler Trucks North America, a unit of Germany’s Daimler AG DAI, +0.34% unveiled the SuperTruck earlier this year, part of a program sponsored by the Department of Energy that tasked truck-makers to improve freight efficiency and reduce emissions from big rigs — the kind that carry 70% of the freight shipped on U.S. roads.
The concept truck, built under Daimler’s Freightliner brand, ran a 312-mile round trip on Interstate 35 between San Antonio and Dallas, Texas, averaging 12.2 miles per gallon of diesel. Most trucks burn twice that much fuel, the company said.
Some technologies used in the SuperTruck are far off in terms of mass production. For instance, the SuperTruck engineers used a hybrid-electric powertrain and waste-heat recovery technology that aren’t commercially viable yet. But some are. For example, the truck has “eCoast”, which automatically disengages the transmission when the truck is coasting.
Solar panels run the length of the truck’s trailer, helping to charge the battery, which in turn powers the trailer’s heating and/or air conditioning system. Freightliner engineers spent five years developing the truck.
